s.text: But, except in the highly attenuated sense that Saunders was boosting the ratings of radio stations that were playing LaVerne Baker and Little Richard and the Cadillacs and the Coasters, she wasn't really putting money into these groups' pockets (or, as was more often the case, these groups' record labels' pockets)--as she would have been doing had she bought their records after hearing them on the radio.
She brought a record player, we brought our 45s (my contribution was "Rock Around the Clock"), and two dozen 11- and 12-year-olds danced for two hours!
She brought a record player, we brought our 45s (my contribution was "Rock Around the Clock"), and two dozen 11- and 12-year-olds danced for two hours!
(Interestingly, my dad and I later developed a great relationship, and he swore he couldn't remember the incident.
I never let him do that again, and I never forgot that lesson about the way authority figures can screw you.
Because of rock, we had a lot in common with each other that neither our parents nor our older siblings or older friends shared.
